user_message:
Target function code is:
```c
int lfs_mount(lfs_t *lfs, const struct lfs_config *cfg) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_mount(%p, %p {.context=%p, "
                ".read=%p, .prog=%p, .erase=%p, .sync=%p, "
                ".read_size=%"PRIu32", .prog_size=%"PRIu32", "
                ".block_size=%"PRIu32", .block_count=%"PRIu32", "
                ".block_cycles=%"PRId32", .cache_size=%"PRIu32", "
                ".lookahead_size=%"PRIu32", .read_buffer=%p, "
                ".prog_buffer=%p, .lookahead_buffer=%p, "
                ".name_max=%"PRIu32", .file_max=%"PRIu32", "
                ".attr_max=%"PRIu32"})",
            (void*)lfs, (void*)cfg, cfg->context,
            (void*)(uintptr_t)cfg->read, (void*)(uintptr_t)cfg->prog,
            (void*)(uintptr_t)cfg->erase, (void*)(uintptr_t)cfg->sync,
            cfg->read_size, cfg->prog_size, cfg->block_size, cfg->block_count,
            cfg->block_cycles, cfg->cache_size, cfg->lookahead_size,
            cfg->read_buffer, cfg->prog_buffer, cfg->lookahead_buffer,
            cfg->name_max, cfg->file_max, cfg->attr_max);

    err = lfs_mount_(lfs, cfg);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_mount -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(cfg);
    return err;
}
```

Static call graph of the target function is:



List additional symbols that are required to analyze the target function to determine if the target function code violates the following MISRA C rule:
A for loop shall be well-formed. The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop count and optionally loop flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with essentially Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement.
The list will be included in the prompt for the next agent, so be concise and clear.
Explain why each symbol is required in the analysis of the target function for the MISRA C rule.
explanation:
Reasoning for each required symbol (concise):

- lfs_mount_: This is the direct implementation invoked by lfs_mount. Any for-loops in lfs_mount_ (or functions it calls) are part of lfs_mount's behaviour and must be inspected for MISRA well-formedness.

- lfs_init, lfs_pair_isnull, lfs_tortoise_detectcycles, lfs_dir_fetchmatch, lfs_tag_isdelete, lfs_dir_get, lfs_superblock_fromle32, lfs_fs_disk_version_major, lfs_fs_disk_version_minor, lfs_fs_prepsuperblock, lfs_min, lfs_dir_getgstate, lfs_gstate_iszero, lfs_tag_isvalid, lfs_alloc_drop, lfs_unmount_: These are the callees of lfs_mount_. Any for-loops inside these functions (or their callees) count as part of lfs_mount's behaviour. You must inspect each to verify: loop-counter initialization (first clause), loop-test side-effects (second clause), loop increment modifications (third clause), whether the loop counter is the only counter and is not modified in the body, and whether functions called in the loop body modify loop-control objects.

- LFS_LOCK, LFS_UNLOCK, LFS_TRACE: These macros expand into code that is lexically inside lfs_mount. Macros can contain loops or modify objects used in nearby loops; their expansions must be reviewed for any for-loops or side-effects that affect loop-control objects.

- struct lfs_config, lfs_t: Definitions of the types used by lfs_mount/lfs_mount_ are needed to determine which objects (members, pointers) are referenced or modified inside loops and whether those objects are loop counters, flags, or otherwise relevant to the MISRA clauses.

Notes: The MISRA requirement treats the behaviour of functions called inside a for-loop as part of the loop body. Therefore the full transitive implementations reachable from lfs_mount_ must be examined; the list above is the immediate set from the static call graph plus the macros and type definitions that can affect loop structure and side-effects. If any of the listed functions themselves call additional functions, those implementations must also be included in the analysis.
